7.40.text:
A week and a half passed since we placed the
glass urn into a sealed box

14.10.text:
with a jar full of acetone to start dismantling
the old joins.

19.71.text:
About four days I left the urn in the sealed
environment

24.15.text:
to see actually if the acetone would start
softening the adhesive

28.51.text:
and the joins would start moving. However, nothing
happened,

35.19.text: So I decided to think about other methods,

37.89.text:
you know, how can I actually fasten the process
a little bit.

41.61.text: First I decided to use some cotton wool pieces,

48.12.text:
and I started applying them directly onto
the old joins

54.94.text:
to introduce the acetone directly onto the
adhesive.

59.08.text: However, unfortunately it wasn't really effective.

62.36.text:
The ageing of the old adhesive, the thickness
you can see here,

67.01.text:
the thickness of the glass itself and the
tight joins on the edges

72.19.text:
made the whole process much harder than I
thought.

75.03.text:
Then I decided to place the glass urn into
a vacuum chamber

82.36.text:
following the same principle as creating a
sealed environment with acetone.

86.63.text: However, after two days of trying this method,

90.00.text:
nothing happened, so again none of the old
joins were moving.

93.94.text: So I decided that I’m going to start trying

97.47.text:
actually placing the whole object into an
acetone bath

101.80.text: and I left it overnight to see

104.39.text:
this direct application of acetone inside
the old joins,

111.08.text: whether this would work or not.

112.61.text:
When I came the next morning something was
happening but again the joins were still quite

119.09.text:
A colleague of mine suggested to me that hot
water

124.07.text: just application of hot water might also help.

128.21.text: So I filled a large tray with hot water

131.97.text:
and I placed the object exactly in the same
position as it was in the acetone bath, the

137.28.text:
and about I think five seconds, five to ten
seconds

142.91.text:
I realised that all the joins on that side
came apart.

150.95.text:
repeated the same method, putting it into
the hot water bath,

154.86.text:
so in about I would say in an hour
the whole jar came apart.

161.23.text:
I did some documentation of course. Before
I dismantled the jar,

167.88.text:
so as you can see here, as the fragments came
apart I numbered them

172.68.text:
and each fragment they have little kind of
numbers on them

177.33.text:
so when I start reconstructing I know which
way to build,

181.02.text:
and currently I'm still in the stage of deciding.
Because this is an archaeological glass,

186.71.text:
it is important to use an adhesive which will
not be stronger than the glass itself

193.00.text:
but will be strong enough for this sound and
heavy object

198.27.text:
to travel around the world and also be displayed
safely.
